5.20.text:
In many ways the Falklands War was the first
war of the modern age, using satellite surveillance,

9.12.text:
night observation and the very latest weaponry
that military technology had to offer.

13.01.text:
While in previous eras there was only one perception 
of combat experience, that of close-quarter fighting,

17.20.text:
technological advances throughout history, 
and the 20th century in particular,

21.62.text:
had greatly diversified combat experience.
But many times, particularly in the land war,

26.39.text:
for all its technological sophistication,
however, the fighting over the Falklands resembled

29.80.text:
that of the First World War, with heavily defended 
positions being fought over at close quarter.

35.55.text:
How did this direct confrontation of the enemy,
experienced almost exclusively by the ground forces,

39.27.text:
influence the mentalities of the men
involved in the fighting? And how did these

43.16.text:
contrast with those of the men involved in
the ferocious, highly technological war at

47.72.text:
sea and in the air? Through analysis of these
contrasts, this lecture will demonstrate the

51.99.text:
different and complex combat experience of
the British servicemen in the Falklands War.

56.83.text:
The first area I’d like to explore is the
different reasons for joining the Armed Forces

60.22.text:
in the '60s, '70s and early '80s and the expectation
of what service entailed, as these had a direct

65.42.text:
influence on the cultures of the branches
of the Armed Forces, which would in turn later

71.45.text:
Unlike the First and Second World Wars, the
Falklands War was not marked by a rush to colours

74.11.text:
by idealistic youths and volunteers,
nor was there any conscription.

78.32.text:
The men who fought in the South Atlantic were paid 
and highly trained professionals; indeed they were

81.69.text:
already members of the Armed Forces when
the crisis began. These men had not joined up

85.41.text:
under the pretence of ideology or a particularly
strong desire to defend 'Queen and Country'.

89.97.text:
The vast majority of soldiers serving in the
British Army had joined during a time of peace

92.96.text:
and, as [Hugh] McManners has written, ‘Joining
the Armed Forces in peacetime, with no immediate

97.00.text:
prospect of having to go to war, was presented
by recruiters as a career like any other.’

101.84.text:
Men joined the different branches of the British
Armed Forces for a variety of reasons.

105.17.text:
For some, particularly those in the Royal Navy,
it was the non-warlike opportunities offered

107.96.text:
by the service, including foreign travel,
trade apprenticeships or family connections

111.56.text:
that enticed them to join. For others, it was 
the sporting opportunities that the services provided.

117.54.text:
Sport was used by the Ministry of Defence
as a major incentive in their recruitment

120.01.text:
drives and it featured heavily and consistently
in recruitment pamphlets distributed by both

125.14.text:
the various regiments of the Army and the
Royal Marines in the 1960s and 1970s, with

129.18.text:
specific sections detailing the importance of 
competitive sport. Indeed, in a 1972 recruitment

134.34.text:
pamphlet produced for the Army, it stated
that, ‘You would have to be a very rich

137.26.text:
civilian indeed to take part in all the sports
available to the average infantry man.’

140.76.text:
Now, moving on to the concept of prior service
before the Falklands (because these also had

147.92.text:
a significant impact on what was expected)
the likelihood of military service and the

154.58.text:
operations with which the individual armed
forces were engaged in, had a direct impact

157.92.text:
upon their institutional culture and thus
shaped outlooks and opinions for those who

161.47.text:
joined them. Except for a 12-month period
between 1967 and 1968, British soldiers have

167.43.text:
been killed on operations every year since
the end of the Second World War. Thus, British

170.90.text:
servicemen have always had the thought and
likelihood of combat in the forefront of their

173.85.text:
minds and the vast majority of such operations
were carried out by the Army.

177.58.text:
The British Army’s longstanding operation
in Northern Ireland, whereby all units,

181.14.text:
bar the Ghurkhas, did rotational tours of the
province, meant that the men had some inkling

184.77.text:
of life on active service. In the infantry,
without a conventional war, service in

188.91.text:
Northern Ireland was seen as the proving ground, 
if not the culmination of military training.

192.43.text:
One Royal Marine has recalled that during
his training Northern Ireland became increasingly

195.69.text:
important and that a new recruit could have
no doubts he would serve there:

199.59.text:
‘When they put you through training, you obviously 
learn lots, so if you didn't know it before you

202.31.text:
go in, you’re going to know it when you’ve
finished training. And this is what we expected

205.14.text: to do, because it’s part of the job.’

207.43.text:
Indeed, in 1975 the Ministry of Information
even produced a pamphlet for

211.35.text:
the Ministry of Defence entitled, 
‘Northern Ireland: What’s it like for Soldiers?’

214.91.text:
This pamphlet aimed to explain how and why the 
soldiers would operate in Northern Ireland.

218.45.text:
While not every recruit would have seen such a 
pamphlet, that the Ministry of Defence was producing

221.76.text:
them demonstrates they were trying to educate
the recruits as to the likelihood of active service.

225.33.text:
Those that did see it could have
no doubt that they would be expected to serve

228.47.text:
in the province. One personal question regarding
soldiers in Northern Ireland covered in it is,

233.93.text:
‘Are they allowed to refuse to serve
there?’ to which the answer is,

237.80.text:
‘No, soldiers know they have to go 
where they are needed.’

240.20.text:
There is, therefore, an expectation of active
service; military service is expected, indeed

243.73.text:
it is a desirable aspect of serving in the
Army, it is part of the job. Such attitudes

247.53.text:
had a marked effect on combat experience,
as shall be discussed later. However, while

251.90.text:
it provided similar stresses to combat, the
fact remained that Northern Ireland was a

254.71.text:
counter-insurgency policing operation, not
a conventional war. Anti-terrorist activities

259.16.text:
may provide good training but the risks are
not the same. Exposure to enemy fire was not

263.06.text:
as prolonged, nor was the intensity of violence
as high. In war there is no respite from the

267.88.text:
work, the danger and the psychological tension
that goes with them.

270.38.text:
The soldiers who had served in Northern Ireland
were very aware of this despite all its manifest

273.48.text:
dangers and that it was not the same as a
conventional war. As one Royal Marine said,

277.42.text:
‘Having been a soldier in Northern Ireland
is a different role, a different job,

281.34.text: it’s a different type of war.’

282.75.text:
George Brown, who served in 3 Para during
the Falklands War, but had also served in

286.44.text:
Suez, Aden and Northern Ireland, referred
to the idea of ‘the unseen enemy’ in the province,

290.42.text:
where there were ‘people talking to you, 
smiling at you, who hate your guts

293.62.text:
and who would then retreat around a corner
and try and kill you!’

296.10.text:
Christopher Brown had served in South Armagh,
‘But I’d never seen a general war.

300.34.text:
As you’ll appreciate, Northern Ireland, even
in South Armagh, is very, very different from

303.64.text:
the general war situation in which we later
found ourselves in the Falklands.

307.53.text:
It’s a feature of Northern Ireland that one very
seldom comes face-to-face with a terrorist,

310.95.text:
it’s far more likely to be the victim of
an explosion or a rocket attack, where one

314.28.text:
doesn’t actually see the man that’s pushing
the button.’

316.02.text:
However, while Northern Ireland was very different
from the conventional war in which the British

320.72.text:
had been engaged in the Falklands, such experience
did in fact create a desire for such a conflict.

324.59.text:
This can be seen in the enthusiastic welcome
for which the news of the South Atlantic crisis

328.08.text:
was greeted and there was a real rush to ensure
that men took part and were not left behind.

333.08.text:
The desire amongst the Army and Royal Marines
to participate in the largest military action

336.31.text:
Britain had conducted since Korea far outweighed
the confusion over where this action would

339.95.text:
take place. I’m sure you know this or have
read it somewhere but a great number of British

344.47.text:
servicemen could not quite fathom neither
why nor how Argentina might invade islands

348.34.text:
off the coast of Scotland without them realising
first. [Laughter]

352.70.text:
For many, the possibility represented by the
Falklands represented a real purpose and meant

358.58.text:
that the years of training were suddenly going
to be put into action. This was the product

362.15.text:
of the mental conformity that came from training
and serving in these units and of buying into

369.52.text:
John Geddes, of 2 Para, for example, nearly
missed the embarkation because he was on leave

373.21.text:
and his words, and I quote, ‘If I had missed
the boat trip to the Falklands, I know that

376.42.text:
I would have spent the rest of my days branded
a coward who bottled out of the battle. The

380.08.text:
men I admired most, my mates, would have shunned
me. I would have become a Parachute Regiment

387.02.text:
leper and as far as I’m concerned that would
have been the worst disease on the planet.’

390.32.text:
And he concludes, ‘In those days the regiment
and your mates were everything.’

395.44.text:
Desire to participate amongst the ordinary
soldier was not for any lofty political or

398.34.text:
moral reason (although obviously there was
this is the contemporary media). For one para,

403.66.text:
‘The idea of going to the Falklands is not
that we wanted to save one of our islands

407.44.text:
in the South Atlantic, it was just the business
that some country was trying to knock

410.40.text:
Great Britain off the pile, so it was going down
there to sort the Argentineans out, not so

414.16.text: much to go and save the Falkland Islanders.’

416.02.text:
Indeed, it was a desire to implement training
and utilise the skills learnt, to test oneself

419.91.text:
in the ultimate environment, which inspired
people to go. It’s important as well to

424.39.text:
know that this attitude was not just present
amongst the more elite units of the British

428.19.text:
Armed Forces, the Parachute Regiment and the
Royal Marines, who went south, but it was

433.71.text:
Robert Lawrence, for example, who served with
the Scots Guards, was concerned about the

437.30.text:
impending action only so much that he was
worried that by the time he arrived south,

440.40.text:
the Royal Marines would already have won the
war and he’d have nothing to do. For Lawrence,

444.24.text:
and I quote, ‘Our feelings on the journey
down to the Falklands were mixed. We swung

447.27.text:
at times from being desperately scared of
the realities of going to war, to being just

450.87.text:
as desperately worried that we’d get down
there merely to be told we were just garrisoning

453.78.text:
the islands and that the Marines had more
or less done all the work.’

457.08.text:
Indeed, Lawrence was resentful of the coverage
the Paras and Royal Marines received in comparison

460.89.text:
to the Guards, quoting, ‘I’m a trained
killer, you know - every bit as good as these

464.17.text:
Marines and Paras. I’m sick to death of
hearing about Marines and bloody Paras!’

469.69.text:
Similarly, the vast majority of fighter pilots
were also desperate to take the opportunity

473.55.text:
to implement their training. As one put it,
‘For some, going to war was a shock,

477.30.text:
for others it was a dream come true. The latter
was the case as far as I was concerned.

481.67.text:
Indeed, in my heart of hearts, I wanted to fight.
Peacetime flying had been fun, more than that,

485.34.text:
it had been terrific, but it wasn’t 
"the real McCoy" and only the real thing was going

489.46.text:
to show us if all our training and tactics
were good enough.’

491.51.text:
There was certainly a professional satisfaction
to be gained from putting training to the

495.40.text:
test and this created a real dichotomy of
personal feeling when contrasted with the

499.14.text:
personal fears that were inevitably present,
especially as the British fighter pilots were

504.39.text:
In contrast, from my research it is clear
that the prevalent attitude amongst those

507.15.text:
who joined the Navy service fleet in the 1960s,
'70s and early '80s was one whereby the possibility

512.34.text:
of seeing action at all was seen as being
extremely unlikely and remote.

516.13.text:
Kevin Smith, for example, said that, when considering 
whether to join the Navy, the idea to ever be involved

520.49.text:
in a war never crossed his mind, whereas he
knew that if he joined the Army and the Marines

523.80.text: then it would be a definite.

524.67.text:
Such an attitude arose partly due to the political
circumstances surrounding the Navy in the

528.71.text:
post-war period and Naval recruitment undoubtedly
benefited from the extended period of peace

533.52.text:
that the Navy was involved in. Thus, the Navy
was able to extol all the benefits of

537.57.text:
Armed Forces life without any of the negatives 
and in particular the incentive of

541.43.text: foreign travel was a major draw.

543.51.text:
This is from a 1973 calendar produced by the
Navy in order to, as I said, entice recruits

550.38.text:
and, as you can see here, the vast majority
of this is given over to really just extolling

554.44.text:
the wonderful places you can go. And in an
age pre- sort of cheap air fare and cheap

560.58.text:
air travel, that’s quite a major incentive
and certainly something that a lot of people

563.96.text:
were very receptive to. In the top-left up
here you’ve got Venice, bottom-left-hand

568.52.text:
side there is in Singapore and on the right-hand
side is this generally pleasant Mediterranean scene.

574.88.text:
Alastair Finlan has argued that, ‘While
servicemen have joined a profession in which

579.19.text:
the fundamental purpose is to apply violence
(often lethal) to achieve political ends,

583.11.text:
they rarely practise the skills they have
learnt,’ and this is particularly true of

585.89.text:
the Royal Navy in the period of 1960-82. While
one sailor, John Wingate, believes that when

591.02.text:
he joined the Navy he had a strong sense of
patriotism, he said, and I quote,

594.41.text:
‘I had no sort of feelings when I was joining the
Navy that it might be because I would have

597.07.text:
to go to war or get into any conflict, it
didn't cross my mind.’

600.82.text:
Thus when war became a distinct possibility,
there was not the same widespread enthusiasm

604.02.text:
within the Royal Navy as in the Royal Marines,
as combat was seen as something very alien

608.45.text:
to what it was perceived the Navy did. Therefore,
men who did not consider war a possibility

612.55.text:
when they joined the Navy, suddenly found
themselves thrust into it and this certainly

615.57.text: affects their reactions to what they experienced.

617.95.text:
Even the Submarine Service was forced to adapt,
as they were tactically and culturally orientated

621.32.text:
against hunting out ballistic missile submarines
of the Soviet Navy, in the North Atlantic

624.61.text:
and North Sea, and carried out intelligence
gathering operations. Yet in the Falklands

628.69.text:
they’d be required to fulfil the role of their 
historical predecessors and target Argentine shipping.

634.78.text:
Moving on then to the actual combat itself
and, the first part, to knowing your enemy.

641.08.text:
Despite being tactically and strategically
orientated to fight against two very different

643.82.text:
enemies to the Argentines, the land forces
deployed by the British would be engaged in

647.24.text:
much the same sort of battles for which they
had trained. Their training was directly applicable

650.96.text:
to the situation in hand and, even more significantly,
it was far better than that which the opposing

655.43.text:
Argentine conscripts had received, meaning
that they could approach the coming operation

658.88.text: with the utmost confidence, if some trepidation.

661.95.text:
In order to recapture the islands, the British
would have to engage the Argentines and defeat

664.92.text:
them in combat. As McManners has written,
‘When all the theorising and jargon is removed,

669.26.text:
land combat, more than any form of warfare,
is about killing other human beings.’

672.72.text:
What then motivated the British in this and what
factors shaped their combat experience?

677.52.text:
The Roman historian Tacitus has written that,
‘It is human nature to hate the man you

681.32.text:
have hurt,’ and often, in books focusing
on the role of combat experience and the nature

685.68.text:
of combat experience, there seems to be a
real focus on the dehumanising of the enemy

690.07.text:
and the demonising of his systems, his personality,
his nationality, in order to be able to commit

695.30.text:
acts of violence. However, I consider the
absolute opposite to be true in regards to

698.86.text:
British soldiers in the Falklands: there’s
simply no evidence to suggest that this is

704.66.text:
While the British Army and Marines of 1982
had many disparaging comments to say about

708.54.text:
their enemy, they didn't hate them. Indeed,
it is the professionalism of the soldiers

711.60.text:
in the 1982 Armed Forces that prevented such
hate, since to be effective combat soldiers

716.57.text:
fighting against a numerically superior enemy
in pre-prepared defensive positions,

720.28.text:
they needed to retain a rational thought process,
not give in to wild bloodlust.

724.02.text:
Also, in many ways there was simply no time
for such hate to be fostered. The escalation

728.17.text:
of hostilities occurred so rapidly, the enemy
was so unexpected and the theatre of operations

732.09.text:
so surprising and before they were in a combat
situation, no British soldier could have hated

736.07.text:
such an unforeseen enemy. Even though they
didn't know where the Falklands were -

741.71.text:
and, I mean, that surely in itself would have 
prevented any longstanding, long-term and

748.47.text:
The vast majority of fighting in the Falklands
took place at night. It was terrifying,

752.28.text:
close-quarter combat, where virtually all feelings were
pushed aside and replaced by unconscious survival

755.65.text:
instincts of aggression. While the professionalism
of the British soldiers certainly made them

759.56.text:
effective killing instruments, such work was
not revelled in. The feelings of open hostility

762.91.text:
and aggression whilst carrying out such an
attack were countered by the immediate remorse

766.40.text:
felt after the moment of killing which, to
my mind, quite clearly demonstrates that any

770.91.text:
such emotions felt in the heat of combat were
not deep-set.

775.28.text:
In this, the British Armed Forces in 1982
are sort of historically parallel with their

780.63.text:
predecessors. If you look at the Second World
War, for example, the British respected their

784.99.text:
enemy for their military effectiveness and
capabilities and such respect ultimately prevents

789.62.text:
the fostering of hate. And on the front line,
the British soldier readily identified with

795.08.text:
Gerald Barnett, who served in Italy in 1943
observed that, ‘Because we’re all in the

798.43.text:
same boat, there was an instant strange friendship
that happens between infantry soldiers, even

801.87.text:
on both sides.’ Another soldier, who served
in North Africa, was adamant that he did not

805.74.text:
hate the Germans, that, ‘In the front line
we do not hate those who we try to kill.

809.73.text:
A species of common humanity is developed between
two opposing armies. After all, a dead German,

813.99.text:
a dead Italian and a dead Britisher are pitifully
similar.’

816.47.text:
For him, the spirit of hatred belongs at home
with the civilians, almost exclusively created

821.18.text:
by an aggressively nationalistic and xenophobic
media. And it’s fair to say that there are

825.26.text:
many strong parallels again between that and
the Falklands War. One of the typical headlines

832.02.text:
being produced by ‘The Sun’ [shows image
of ‘Stick It Up Your Junta’ headline].

833.24.text:
Obviously there’s the far more famous ‘Gotcha’
one as well.

837.22.text:
This lack of hate in the Second World War
was often at odds with those experienced by

841.19.text:
senior commanders, whose responsibility was
to foster aggressive tendencies in their men,

844.95.text:
in order to accomplish their missions. For
example, on the eve of the invasion of Sicily,

848.97.text:
Montgomery addressed the 8th Army with the
words, and I quote, ‘Someone said to me

852.01.text:
a few days ago that the Italians are really
decent people and that if we treat them properly,

855.23.text:
they will come over to us. I disagree with
him. Our job is to kill them, that is what

859.17.text:
you have to do. Once we have killed them,
we can see if they’re good fellows or not,

862.62.text: but they must be killed first.’

865.92.text:
Indeed, the lack of hate in the Falklands
can also be seen in how the British soldiers

870.54.text:
interacted with their Argentine enemy once
the fighting was over. Any artificial construct

874.84.text:
of who the enemy were and what they were like
melted as soon as the first social contact

878.46.text:
was made outside of direct engagement. This
normally took the basic form of sharing cigarettes

883.43.text:
with the defeated and captured enemy, but also 
included medically treating wounded Argentine soldiers.

887.60.text:
As one para commented on his first
sight of the enemy after the Battle of Longdon,

890.78.text:
‘I looked at him with interest. He was my
first sight of the enemy. He was like any

895.24.text: of us, only his uniform was different.’

897.73.text:
Furthermore, as the battles were fought so
far from Britain, in isolation, there was

901.84.text:
a real sense among the British of a shared
bond with the Argentines, who had similarly

905.36.text:
endured the campaign. This was particularly
apparent for David Cooper, the padre of 2 Para,

910.27.text:
who said that, and I quote, ‘We all
felt, in a curious way, closer to the Argentines

914.43.text:
who we’d been fighting, than we did to the
people back here because they were the only

918.71.text:
ones who really knew what it was like.’
As McManners has written, ‘Close combat

924.35.text:
gives a human face to the enemy and makes
men realise that he suffers too.’

928.34.text:
Yet if such social identification was possible,
why then did the British engage the Argentines

933.10.text:
so enthusiastically and so effectively? To
my mind, the answer lies in their training.

937.87.text:
Central to the training that each man had
endured, was that they were expected to be

941.26.text:
able to kill in order to achieve their objectives.
When it came to fighting in the Falklands,

944.84.text:
therefore, the British soldiers and Marines
required less mental pressure to take up arms

948.26.text:
and fight, as they already viewed it as their
function and their role. In this way they

951.62.text:
were remarkably different from the civilian
soldiers of the First and Second World Wars,

955.44.text:
who required a bit more mental conditioning
to overcome these social taboos.

960.64.text:
For example, when it came to small arms training,
something all soldiers participated in regularly,

964.40.text:
a pamphlet produced and circulated by the
Director of Army Training in 1973 stated that,

969.32.text:
‘The title of this pamphlet, "Shoot to Kill",
may seem somewhat dramatic but these three

973.15.text:
words sum up exactly the purpose of small
arms training.’

975.55.text:
Additionally, firing ranges had been adapted
to include more realistic Figure 11 targets,

980.60.text:
that looked more like human beings and dropped
away when hit. Throughout the training period,

985.13.text:
and I quote here, ‘The soldiers rehearse
the processes so many times that when he does

988.89.text:
kill in combat he is able to at one level deny himself 
that he is actually killing another human being.’

994.33.text:
Indeed the training was so effective that
one veteran of the campaign recalls that when

997.16.text:
he got into combat in the Falklands and fired
his weapon, it was just like shooting at Figure 11

1000.95.text:
targets on the range, with no greater emotional
significance. Men took no pleasure in what

1005.98.text:
they were doing, they were simply doing their
jobs, fulfilling their vocations as soldiers.

1009.84.text:
As one para commented, and I quote, ‘Some
people make cars, we make war.’

1013.15.text:
Training had also encouraged the essential
esprit de corps that marks the British Army

1018.24.text:
out as being unique. The tribal nature of
the British Army, where regimental pride is

1021.97.text:
promoted above all else, means that men will
go to extraordinary lengths to protect their

1025.65.text:
colleagues, their friends and their regiment.
Soldiers are motivated to acts of violence by -

1030.22.text:
and this sounds rather strange - by acts of love; 
love for their comrades, not in so much a romantic form,

1034.21.text:
but more fraternal bonds that develop between 
men in combat and men in training.

1039.12.text:
As Joanna Bourke has written, ‘It was precisely
the individual’s ability to transcend hatred

1043.71.text:
and to be transported by emotions of love and 
empathy, which facilitated extremes of violence.’

1047.75.text:
The desire to protect one’s
comrades, as well as not risking social exclusion

1051.60.text:
by appearing cowardly in their eyes, motivated
many to participate in attacks on heavily

1055.48.text:
defended positions and fight to capture them.
Training had produced an expected pattern

1059.53.text:
of behaviour and it would take a very brave
man indeed to break out of such habits when

1066.17.text:
Moving on now, in contrast, to look at the
experience of the Navy and the Air Force at war

1070.08.text:
which I’ve termed, ‘Fighting the Faceless’. 
There was another war in the Falklands

1073.74.text:
and one that was still against the
Argentines but, most significantly, it was

1076.74.text:
against their mechanical extensions rather
than people, in terms of ships and aircraft.

1081.24.text:
Whereas on land man fought against man, at
sea and in the air men fought against machine.

1085.07.text:
Such a difference has an enormous effect on
combat experience and motivation.

1089.05.text:
In contrast to the land war, the Royal Navy
could not simply re-orientate itself against
